questions.question: A car accelerates uniformly from an initial velocity of $10\text{ m/s}$ to a final velocity of $30\text{ m/s}$ in a time interval of $5.0\text{ s}$. Calculate the magnitude of the constant acceleration.
questions.explanation: Using $a = \frac{\Delta v}{\Delta t}$: $a = \frac{30 - 10}{5.0} = \frac{20}{5.0} = 4.0\text{ m/s}^2$.

questions.question: A ball is dropped from rest and falls freely under gravity for a time of $2.5\text{ s}$. Neglecting air resistance, calculate the distance fallen. Use $g = 9.8\text{ m/s}^2$.

A projectile is launched from ground level with an initial speed of $25\text{ m/s}$ at an angle of $45^{\circ}$ above the horizontal. Neglecting air resistance, calculate the horizontal range of the projectile.
A train decelerates uniformly from an initial velocity of $40\text{ m/s}$ to a final velocity of $10\text{ m/s}$ over a distance of $150\text{ m}$. Calculate the acceleration of the train.

A stone is dropped from rest from a height of $125\text{ m}$ above the ground. Neglecting air resistance, calculate the velocity of the stone just before it impacts the ground. Use $g = 9.8\text{ m/s}^2$.
questions.explanation: Using $v^2 = u^2 + 2as$: $v^2 = 0 + 2(9.8)(125) = 2450 \rightarrow v = \sqrt{2450} \approx 49.5\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A ball is thrown vertically upward from ground level with an initial velocity of $22\text{ m/s}$. Neglecting air resistance, calculate the maximum height reached by the ball above the ground. Use $g = 9.8\text{ m/s}^2$.
questions.explanation: At maximum height the final velocity is $0$: $h = \frac{u^2}{2g} = \frac{(22)^2}{2(9.8)} = \frac{484}{19.6} \approx 24.7\text{ m}$.

questions.question: A projectile is fired horizontally with an initial speed of $18\text{ m/s}$ from the edge of a cliff that is $45\text{ m}$ tall. Neglecting air resistance, calculate the time of flight until the projectile hits the ground below.
questions.explanation: Vertical motion only determines time of flight: $s = \frac{1}{2}gt^2 \rightarrow 45 = 4.9t^2 \rightarrow t = \sqrt{45/4.9} \approx 3.03\text{ s}$.

questions.question: A boat heads directly across a river, pointing perpendicular to the banks, at a speed of $4.0\text{ m/s}$ relative to the water. The river current flows parallel to the banks at a speed of $3.0\text{ m/s}$. Calculate the magnitude of the boat's resultant velocity relative to an observer on the shore.
questions.explanation: The two velocity components are perpendicular: $v = \sqrt{(4.0)^2 + (3.0)^2} = \sqrt{16+9} = \sqrt{25} = 5.0\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: Car A travels due East at a constant speed of $60\text{ km/h}$ and Car B travels due North at a constant speed of $80\text{ km/h}$. Calculate the magnitude of the velocity of Car A as measured by an observer in Car B (i.e., the magnitude of the relative velocity of Car A with respect to Car B).
questions.explanation: The relative velocity vector is the difference, which has perpendicular components: $|\vec{v}_{A/B}| = \sqrt{60^2 + 80^2} = \sqrt{3600+6400} = \sqrt{10000} = 100\text{ km/h}$.

questions.question: A box with a mass of $15\text{ kg}$ is pulled across a horizontal surface by a horizontal force of $75\text{ N}$. If the box accelerates at $3.0\text{ m/s}^2$, calculate the coefficient of kinetic friction between the box and the surface.
questions.explanation: $F_{net} = ma = 45\text{ N}$. The friction force is $f_k = F_{applied} - F_{net} = 75 - 45 = 30\text{ N}$. $\mu_k = f_k/(mg) = 30/(15 \times 9.8) \approx 0.20$.

questions.question: A hockey puck of mass $2.0\text{ kg}$ slides across ice with an initial speed of $6.0\text{ m/s}$. If the coefficient of kinetic friction between the puck and the ice is $\mu_k = 0.25$, calculate the time it takes for the puck to slide to a stop.
questions.explanation: The deceleration is $a = -\mu_k g = -2.45\text{ m/s}^2$. Using $v = v_0 + at$ with $v=0$: $0 = 6.0 - 2.45t \rightarrow t = 6.0/2.45 \approx 2.45\text{ s}$.

questions.question: Calculate the magnitude of the impulse required to bring a car with a mass of $800\text{ kg}$ traveling at a speed of $25\text{ m/s}$ to a complete stop.
questions.explanation: Impulse $J = \Delta p = m\Delta v = 800(0 - 25) = -20000\text{ N·s}$. The magnitude is $2.0 \times 10^4\text{ N·s}$.

questions.question: A block of mass $8.0\text{ kg}$ rests on a frictionless incline that makes an angle of $25^{\circ}$ with the horizontal. Calculate the magnitude of the component of the block's weight that acts parallel to the surface of the incline.
questions.explanation: $F_{\parallel} = mg\sin\theta = (8.0)(9.8)\sin(25^{\circ}) = 78.4 \times 0.423 \approx 33.1\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A block slides down a frictionless incline that makes an angle of $35^{\circ}$ with the horizontal. Starting from rest, calculate the time it takes for the block to travel a distance of $8.0\text{ m}$ along the incline.
questions.explanation: The acceleration down the incline is $a = g\sin\theta = 9.8\sin(35^{\circ}) = 5.62\text{ m/s}^2$. Using $s = \frac{1}{2}at^2$: $t = \sqrt{2s/a} = \sqrt{16/5.62} \approx 1.69\text{ s}$.

questions.question: In an Atwood machine, two masses, $M_1 = 4.0\text{ kg}$ and $M_2 = 8.0\text{ kg}$, are connected by a light string passing over a frictionless, massless pulley. Calculate the acceleration of the system when it is released from rest.

A $3.0\text{ kg}$ block on a horizontal table with coefficient of kinetic friction $\mu_k = 0.20$ is connected by a light string over a frictionless pulley to a $1.5\text{ kg}$ hanging mass. Calculate the tension in the string when the system is released.
A mass of $2.0\text{ kg}$ is suspended by two identical light strings, each making an angle of $30^{\circ}$ with the vertical. Calculate the tension in each string.
questions.explanation: Vertical equilibrium: $2T\cos(30^{\circ}) = mg = 19.6\text{ N}$. Therefore $T = 19.6/(2 \times 0.866) \approx 11.3\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A person with a mass of $65\text{ kg}$ stands on a scale inside an elevator that is accelerating downward at $1.5\text{ m/s}^2$. What is the reading on the scale (the apparent weight of the person)?
questions.explanation: When accelerating downward, the apparent weight is $N = m(g-a) = 65(9.8-1.5) = 65(8.3) = 539.5 \approx 540\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A wheel of radius $0.40\text{ m}$ rotates at $720\text{ rpm}$ (revolutions per minute). Assuming no slipping, calculate the linear speed of a point on the rim in $\text{m/s}$.
questions.explanation: Angular velocity: $\omega = 720 \times 2\pi/60 = 75.4\text{ rad/s}$. Linear speed: $v = \omega r = 75.4 \times 0.40 \approx 30.2\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: An object moving in uniform circular motion has a centripetal acceleration of $15\text{ m/s}^2$. If the radius of the circular path is $3.0\text{ m}$, calculate the frequency of rotation.
questions.explanation: Centripetal acceleration: $a_c = \omega^2 r \rightarrow \omega = \sqrt{a_c/r} = \sqrt{15/3} = \sqrt{5} = 2.24\text{ rad/s}$. Frequency: $f = \omega/(2\pi) \approx 0.36\text{ Hz}$.

questions.question: A mass of $0.50\text{ kg}$ is attached to a string and whirled in a vertical circle of radius $0.80\text{ m}$. If the speed of the mass at the bottom of the circle is $6.0\text{ m/s}$, calculate the tension in the string at that instant.
Calculate the maximum constant speed at which a car can travel over the crest of a circular hill with a radius of curvature of $40\text{ m}$ without losing contact with the road.
questions.explanation: At the point of losing contact, the normal force becomes zero and gravity provides the centripetal force: $mg = mv^2/r \rightarrow v = \sqrt{gr} = \sqrt{9.8 \times 40} = \sqrt{392} \approx 19.8\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A mass of $0.15\text{ kg}$ is whirled in a horizontal circle of radius $0.60\text{ m}$. If the tension in the string is $3.0\text{ N}$, calculate the speed of the mass.
questions.explanation: For horizontal circular motion, $T = mv^2/r \rightarrow v = \sqrt{Tr/m} = \sqrt{3.0 \times 0.60 / 0.15} = \sqrt{12} \approx 3.46\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A curve on a highway has a radius of $80\text{ m}$ and is designed for a safe speed of $22\text{ m/s}$ with no friction required. Calculate the banking angle of the curve.
questions.explanation: For a banked curve with no friction, $\tan\theta = v^2/(rg) = (22)^2/(80 \times 9.8) = 484/784 = 0.617$. Therefore $\theta = \tan^{-1}(0.617) \approx 31.7^{\circ}$.

questions.question: Calculate the distance between the centers of two objects, each of mass $800\text{ kg}$, if the magnitude of the gravitational force of attraction between them is $2.0 \times 10^{-7}\text{ N}$. Use $G = 6.67 \times 10^{-11}\text{ N·m}^2/\text{kg}^2$.
questions.explanation: Using Newton's law of gravitation: $F = G\frac{m^2}{r^2} \rightarrow r^2 = G\frac{m^2}{F} = (6.67 \times 10^{-11})\frac{(800)^2}{2.0 \times 10^{-7}} = (6.67 \times 10^{-11})\frac{640000}{2.0 \times 10^{-7}} = (6.67 \times 10^{-11})(3.2 \times 10^{12}) = 213.44$. Therefore $r = \sqrt{213.44} \approx 14.6\text{ m}$.

questions.question: A satellite orbits a planet in a circular orbit at a distance $R$ from the planet's center. If the satellite were moved to a new circular orbit at a distance $16R$ from the planet's center, by what factor would its orbital speed change?
questions.explanation: Orbital speed is given by $v = \sqrt{GM/r}$, so $v \propto 1/\sqrt{r}$. If the distance increases by a factor of $16$, the new speed factor is $1/\sqrt{16} = 1/4$.

questions.question: A block of mass $12\text{ kg}$ is pulled at a constant speed a distance of $15\text{ m}$ up a rough incline. If the constant kinetic friction force acting on the block is $15\text{ N}$, calculate the work done by the friction force on the block.
questions.explanation: Work done by friction is $W = -f_k d$, where the negative sign indicates that friction opposes the motion. Therefore $W = -(15)(15) = -225\text{ J}$.

questions.question: A ball of mass $0.12\text{ kg}$ is moving horizontally at a speed of $35\text{ m/s}$ when it is caught and stopped by a fielder. If the fielder's hand moves backward $0.40\text{ m}$ while stopping the ball, calculate the average force exerted by the ball on the hand.
questions.explanation: The initial kinetic energy is $KE = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 = 0.5(0.12)(35)^2 = 73.5\text{ J}$. This energy is dissipated as work done by the average force: $W = Fd \rightarrow F = W/d = 73.5/0.40 \approx 184\text{ N}$.

questions.question: Calculate the net work required to accelerate a car of mass $1500\text{ kg}$ from a speed of $12\text{ m/s}$ to a speed of $24\text{ m/s}$. Assume all work done goes into changing the kinetic energy.

A mass of $1.5\text{ kg}$ is fired vertically upward from a spring gun. The spring has a spring constant $k = 600\text{ N/m}$ and is compressed by $0.15\text{ m}$ before firing. Neglecting air resistance and the mass of the spring, calculate the maximum height reached by the mass above its launch point.
questions.explanation: The elastic potential energy stored in the spring is $PE_s = \frac{1}{2}kx^2 = 0.5(600)(0.15)^2 = 6.75\text{ J}$. This converts to gravitational potential energy at the maximum height: $mgh = 6.75 \rightarrow h = 6.75/(1.5 \times 9.8) \approx 0.46\text{ m}$.

questions.question: A $4.0\text{ kg}$ block slides from rest down a frictionless ramp from a height of $4.0\text{ m}$. At the bottom of the ramp, it continues along a rough horizontal surface where friction brings it to a stop. If its speed at the very bottom of the ramp is measured to be $5.0\text{ m/s}$, calculate the amount of thermal energy generated due to friction on the horizontal surface.
questions.explanation: Initial gravitational potential energy: $PE_i = mgh = (4.0)(9.8)(4.0) = 156.8\text{ J}$. Kinetic energy at the bottom: $KE_f = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 = 0.5(4.0)(5.0)^2 = 50\text{ J}$. The energy lost to friction is $156.8 - 50 \approx 107\text{ J}$, which is converted to thermal energy.

questions.question: An electric motor with an efficiency of $70\%$ draws $1200\text{ W}$ of electrical power. At what constant speed can this motor lift a load of mass $60\text{ kg}$ vertically upward?
questions.explanation: Useful power output: $P_{out} = \text{efficiency} \times P_{in} = 0.70 \times 1200 = 840\text{ W}$. For lifting at constant speed, $P_{out} = Fv = mgv$, so $v = P_{out}/(mg) = 840/(60 \times 9.8) \approx 1.43\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: Calculate the horsepower required to lift a load of mass $150\text{ kg}$ vertically upward a distance of $20\text{ m}$ in $8.0\text{ s}$. Use the conversion $1\text{ hp} = 746\text{ W}$.
questions.explanation: Work done: $W = mgh = (150)(9.8)(20) = 29400\text{ J}$. Power: $P = W/t = 29400/8 = 3675\text{ W}$. Horsepower: $3675/746 \approx 4.93\text{ hp}$.

questions.question: A block of mass $1.5\text{ kg}$ moves horizontally at $5.0\text{ m/s}$ and collides with a light horizontal spring with spring constant $k = 1000\text{ N/m}$. Assuming no friction, calculate the maximum compression of the spring.
questions.explanation: The kinetic energy of the block converts to elastic potential energy in the spring: $\frac{1}{2}mv^2 = \frac{1}{2}kx^2 \rightarrow x = \sqrt{mv^2/k} = \sqrt{(1.5)(25)/1000} = \sqrt{0.0375} \approx 0.19\text{ m}$.

questions.question: If $20\text{ J}$ of work is required to stretch a particular spring by $8.0\text{ cm}$ from its natural length, how much work (in J) is required to stretch it an additional $8.0\text{ cm}$ (i.e., from $8.0\text{ cm}$ to $16\text{ cm}$)?
questions.explanation: Work done on a spring is proportional to the square of the displacement: $W \propto x^2$. If $20\text{ J}$ stretches it by $8\text{ cm}$, then stretching it by $16\text{ cm}$ requires $20 \times (16/8)^2 = 20 \times 4 = 80\text{ J}$. The additional work from $8\text{ cm}$ to $16\text{ cm}$ is $80 - 20 = 60\text{ J}$.

questions.question: A car of mass $1200\text{ kg}$ moving at $18\text{ m/s}$ collides head-on and locks bumpers with a stationary truck of mass $1800\text{ kg}$. Assuming the collision is perfectly inelastic, calculate the final velocity of the combined wreck immediately after the collision.
questions.explanation: Conservation of momentum: $m_1v_1 + m_2v_2 = (m_1 + m_2)v_f$. Therefore $(1200)(18) + (1800)(0) = (3000)v_f \rightarrow v_f = 21600/3000 = 7.2\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: In a perfectly elastic head-on collision, a ball of mass $1.5\text{ kg}$ moving at $6.0\text{ m/s}$ strikes a stationary ball of mass $3.0\text{ kg}$. Calculate the final velocity of the $3.0\text{ kg}$ ball immediately after the collision.
questions.explanation: For an elastic collision where the target is initially at rest, the velocity of the target after collision is given by $v_2 = \frac{2m_1}{m_1+m_2}u_1 = \frac{2(1.5)}{4.5}(6.0) = \frac{3}{4.5}(6.0) = 4.0\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: An object of mass $0.80\text{ kg}$ initially at rest explodes into two pieces. One piece of mass $0.30\text{ kg}$ moves away at $15\text{ m/s}$ due West. Calculate the kinetic energy of the other piece, which has a mass of $0.50\text{ kg}$, immediately after the explosion.
questions.explanation: By conservation of momentum: $0 = (0.30)(-15) + (0.50)v_2 \rightarrow v_2 = (4.5)/(0.50) = 9.0\text{ m/s}$ (East). The kinetic energy is $KE = \frac{1}{2}(0.50)(9.0)^2 = 0.25 \times 81 = 20.25 \approx 20.3\text{ J}$.

questions.question: A $15\text{ V}$ battery is connected in series with a $120\Omega$ resistor and a $180\Omega$ resistor. Calculate the voltage drop across the $120\Omega$ resistor.
questions.explanation: Total resistance: $R_{total} = 120 + 180 = 300\Omega$. Current: $I = V/R_{total} = 15/300 = 0.05\text{ A}$. Voltage across $120\Omega$ resistor: $V = IR = 0.05(120) = 6.0\text{ V}$.

questions.question: Two resistors connected in series have a total equivalent resistance of $750\Omega$. If the ratio of their individual resistances is $2:3$, find the resistance of the smaller resistor.
questions.explanation: Let the resistors be $2R$ and $3R$. Then $2R + 3R = 750 \rightarrow 5R = 750 \rightarrow R = 150$. The smaller resistor is $2R = 300\Omega$.

questions.question: Calculate the equivalent resistance of three resistors, each with a resistance of $150\Omega$, connected in parallel.
questions.explanation: For resistors in parallel: $\frac{1}{R_{eq}} = \frac{1}{150} + \frac{1}{150} + \frac{1}{150} = \frac{3}{150} = \frac{1}{50}$. Therefore $R_{eq} = 50\Omega$.

questions.question: Four identical resistors are connected in parallel. The equivalent resistance of this combination is $15\Omega$. Calculate the resistance of each individual resistor.
questions.explanation: For $n$ identical resistors in parallel, $R_{eq} = R/n$. Here $R_{eq} = R/4 = 15\Omega$, so $R = 4 \times 15 = 60\Omega$.

questions.question: A $30\Omega$ resistor is connected in parallel with another $30\Omega$ resistor. This parallel combination is then connected in series with a $15\Omega$ resistor. Calculate the total equivalent resistance of this circuit.
questions.explanation: The parallel combination: $R_p = \frac{1}{1/30 + 1/30} = \frac{30}{2} = 15\Omega$. Adding the series resistor: $R_{total} = 15 + 15 = 30\Omega$.

questions.question: A $15\text{ V}$ battery is connected to a circuit consisting of a $15\Omega$ resistor in series with a parallel combination of two $30\Omega$ resistors. Calculate the total power dissipated in the circuit.
questions.explanation: The parallel combination: $R_p = \frac{1}{1/30 + 1/30} = 15\Omega$. Total resistance: $R_{total} = 15 + 15 = 30\Omega$. Power: $P = V^2/R_{total} = (15)^2/30 = 225/30 = 7.5\text{ W}$.

questions.question: A wave travels a distance of $30\text{ m}$ in $5.0\text{ s}$. If the wavelength is $0.60\text{ m}$, calculate the frequency of the wave.
questions.explanation: Wave speed: $v = \text{distance}/\text{time} = 30/5.0 = 6.0\text{ m/s}$. Frequency: $f = v/\lambda = 6.0/0.60 = 10\text{ Hz}$.

questions.question: A string of length $1.2\text{ m}$ and total mass $3.0\text{ g}$ is under a tension of $72\text{ N}$. Calculate the fundamental frequency of vibration for this string.
questions.explanation: Linear mass density: $\mu = m/L = 0.003/1.2 = 0.0025\text{ kg/m}$. Wave speed: $v = \sqrt{T/\mu} = \sqrt{72/0.0025} = \sqrt{28800} = 169.7\text{ m/s}$. Fundamental frequency: $f = v/(2L) = 169.7/2.4 \approx 71\text{ Hz}$.

questions.question: A person standing on a stationary platform hears the whistle of a train. The frequency heard as the train approaches is $600\text{ Hz}$, and the frequency heard as it recedes is $480\text{ Hz}$. Assuming the speed of sound is $v_s = 340\text{ m/s}$, calculate the speed of the train.
questions.explanation: Using the Doppler effect: $\frac{f_{approach}}{f_{recede}} = \frac{v_s + v}{v_s - v}$. Substituting: $\frac{600}{480} = \frac{340+v}{340-v} \rightarrow \frac{5}{4} = \frac{340+v}{340-v} \rightarrow 5(340-v) = 4(340+v) \rightarrow 1700 - 5v = 1360 + 4v \rightarrow 340 = 9v \rightarrow v \approx 37.8\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: Two speakers are separated by a distance of $4.0\text{ m}$ and emit a $600\text{ Hz}$ tone in phase. The speed of sound is $340\text{ m/s}$. At what distance from the center point along the line joining the two speakers is the first point of constructive interference located?
questions.explanation: Wavelength: $\lambda = v/f = 340/600 = 0.567\text{ m}$. For constructive interference along the line between the speakers, the path difference is $\Delta = \lambda$ at the first antinode. If $x$ is the distance from the center, then $2x = \lambda \rightarrow x = \lambda/2 = 0.567/2 \approx 0.28\text{ m}$.

questions.question: Calculate the length of a closed-end organ pipe (closed at one end, open at the other) that has a third harmonic frequency of $514.5\text{ Hz}$. Take the speed of sound as $v_s = 343\text{ m/s}$.
questions.explanation: For a closed pipe, the third harmonic frequency is $f_3 = 3v/(4L)$. Solving for length: $L = 3v/(4f_3) = 3(343)/(4 \times 514.5) = 1029/2058 = 0.50\text{ m}$.

questions.question: Two sound waves with frequencies of $400\text{ Hz}$ and $406\text{ Hz}$ interfere. Calculate the beat frequency heard.
questions.explanation: The beat frequency is the absolute difference between the two frequencies: $f_{beat} = |f_2 - f_1| = |406 - 400| = 6\text{ Hz}$.
